passage.text: Intestinal parasitic infections in Thai HIV-infected patients with different immunity status
In case of a tropical epidemic, it is important to focus on the non-opportunistic intestinal parasite infections that are prevalent among HIV-infected patients who present with diarrhea.

The risk of stress-induced gastroduodenal erosions in critically ill patients is high, but the incidence of clinically important complications caused by these erosionening factors often determines the appropriate course of action for administering prophylactic drugs. In contrast, published studies have shown conflicting results based on whether an agent with significant bleeding would be more effective than one with similar efficacy. Our findings indicate that Dictyostelium cells under hypertonic conditions display significant internal acidification, depletion of the internal NTP pool, downregulation of vesicular mobility, block fluid-phase endocytosis, and exocellular activity acting as a signal mediator.
